questions.text: A neonate presents with a growing skin lesion, as shown in the image provided. The mother reports that the lesion has been increasing in size daily. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Immediate Biopsy due to Malignancy Risk

questions.solution:
Infantile hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors that commonly appear within the first few weeks of life. They typically grow rapidly during the first few months (proliferative phase) before undergoing spontaneous involution over several years.

Most do not require intervention unless they cause complications such as airway obstruction, ulceration, or vision impairment.

 

Other options:

 

Excision and Laser Therapy (Option B): Reserved for complicated hemangiomas (e.g., ulcerated, functionally impairing, or rapidly growing in critical areas like the airway or eyes).

 

Immediate Biopsy due to Malignancy Risk (Option C): Unnecessary, as infantile hemangiomas are benign and diagnosed clinically.

 

Cryotherapy (Option D): Not an appropriate treatment for hemangiomas, as they typically regress without intervention.

questions.text: A patient presents with a nodulo-ulcerative lesion on the lower lip, as shown in the image. What is the best way to take a biopsy in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Excisional biopsy:

  • For a suspicious lesion on the lip, which may be pre-cancerous, an excisional biopsy is the most appropriate method, allowing for complete removal and histopathological examination.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are insufficient.

questions.text: What nutritional deficiency is commonly associated with a chronic alcoholic presenting with a pruritic, eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of the hands?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vit B3

Explanation:

The patient is a chronic alcoholic with a pruritic, eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of the hands, which is characteristic of pellagra—a disease caused by niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency.

Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:

  • Dermatitis
    • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
    • Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck
  • Diarrhoea, and
  • Dementia.

Causes of pellagra :

  • Dietary Deficiency- Maize and Sorghum based diet
  • Impaired Tryptophan Metabolism
    • Factors Affecting Tryptophan to Niacin Conversion:
      • Vitamin B6 Deficiency
      • Medications: Isoniazid (INH), OCPs
      • Hormonal Influences: Estrogen metabolites hinder tryptophan metabolism.
      • Genetic Disorders: Inherited conditions like Hartnup disease can impede tryptophan absorption in the intestines and reabsorption in the kidneys
  • Carcinoid Syndrome
  • Other Contributing Factors:
    • Alcoholism: Interferes with nutrient absorption, including niacin and tryptophan.
    • Malabsorption Syndromes

Incorrect Options:

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) Deficiency (Option B): Leads to Beriberi (wet/dry) and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which primarily causes neurological and cardiac symptoms rather than a rash.

Vitamin D Deficiency (Option C): Causes rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, presenting with bone pain and muscle weakness, but no skin rash.

Vitamin C Deficiency (Option D): Leads to scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums, petechiae, impaired wound healing, and corkscrew hairs, but not the photosensitive rash seen in pellagra.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies causes follicular hyperkeratosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vitamin A

Explanation:

Follicular hyperkeratosis is characterized by dry, rough skin with small, keratotic papules around hair follicles, often seen in Vitamin A deficiency. This occurs due to abnormal keratinization of epithelial cells.

Vitamin A Deficiency Manifestations :

1) Ocular manifestations :

  • Vitamin A deficiency is the most significant preventable cause of blindness, especially in children below 5 in developing countries.
  • Early Signs:
    • Loss of sensitivity to green light.
    • Difficulty adapting to dim light.
    • Night blindness.
  • Prolonged Deficiency:
    • Xerophthalmia:
      1. Dry, thick, keratinized conjunctiva and cornea. If untreated, it leads to corneal ulceration and ultimately results in blindness due to the formation of opaque scar tissue.
      2. WHO grading of xerophthalmia:

XN
  • Night blindness.

X1
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis.
  • X1B: Bitot spots.

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.
  • Bitot's Spots: Grayish-white triangular plaques firmly adherent to the conjunctiva.
  • Keratomalacia: When xerophthalmia persists for a longer time, it progresses to keratomalacia (corneal softening).

2) Immune Function:

  • Deficiency increases susceptibility to infections.
  • Infection reduces retinol-binding protein synthesis, lowering vitamin A levels and impairing immune responses.

3) Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions:

  • Follicular Hyperkeratosis (Phrynoderma): Causes rough skin due to hyperkeratinization of the follicular epithelium.
  • Keratinizing Metaplasia: Affects respiratory, gastrointestinal, and genitourinary tracts.
  • Epithelium is atrophied.

4) Other General Manifestation :

  • Growth retardation due to defective synthesis of chondroitin sulfate.
  • Decreased protein synthesis.

Incorrect Options:

Vitamin C Deficiency (Option B): Causes scurvy, leading to corkscrew hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, and poor wound healing, but not follicular hyperkeratosis.

Vitamin E Deficiency (Option C): Causes neurological symptoms (ataxia, peripheral neuropathy, hemolytic anemia) but does not affect keratinization.

Vitamin B6 Deficiency (Option D): Leads to cheilitis, glossitis, irritability, and neuropathy, but not follicular hyperkeratosis.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis of the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Milia

Explanation:

  • The most probable diagnosis based on the image is Milia.

Disease of the newborn not requiring treatment

Sebaceous hyperplasia
  • Minute, profuse, yellow-white papules are frequently found on the forehead, nose, upper lip, and cheeks.
  • Hyperplastic sebaceous glands.

 

Milia
  • Firm cyst, pearly, and opalescent white lesions.
  • Superficial epidermal inclusion cysts that contain laminated keratinized material.

Epstein pearls
  • Milia on the midline of the palate.

Sucking blisters
  • Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs.
  • Induced by vigorous sucking on the affected part in utero.

Salmon patch (Nevus simplex)
  • Small, pale pink, ill-defined, vascular macule that occurs most commonly on the glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area.

Mongolian spots (Dermal melanocytosis)

(Option C)
  • Blue or slate-grey macular lesions most commonly in the sacral area.

Erythema toxicum(Option A)
  • Firm, yellow-white, papules or pustules with a surrounding erythematous flare.
  • Eosinophils are seen in Wright-stained smears
  • Unknown cause.

Pustular melanosis (Option B):

  • It is an idiopathic pustular eruption that heals with brown pigmented macules. It is more common in black neonates.

questions.text: The condition shown in the image below is seen in which vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Niacin

Explanation:

The condition described in the image is Pellagra, which is caused by niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency.

Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:

  • Dermatitis
    • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
    • Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck
  • Diarrhoea, and
  • Dementia.

Causes of pellagra :

  • Dietary Deficiency- Maize and Sorghum based diet
  • Impaired Tryptophan Metabolism
    • Factors Affecting Tryptophan to Niacin Conversion:
      • Vitamin B6 Deficiency
      • Medications: Isoniazid (INH), OCPs
      • Hormonal Influences: Estrogen metabolites hinder tryptophan metabolism.
      • Genetic Disorders: Inherited conditions like Hartnup disease can impede tryptophan absorption in the intestines and reabsorption in the kidneys
  • Carcinoid Syndrome
  • Other Contributing Factors:
    • Alcoholism: Interferes with nutrient absorption, including niacin and tryptophan.
    • Malabsorption Syndromes

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) Deficiency (Option A): Causes cheilitis, glossitis, irritability, and peripheral neuropathy, but not the characteristic photosensitive rash.

Cobalamin (Vitamin B12) Deficiency (Option B): Leads to megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, and glossitis, but not pellagra.

Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) Deficiency (Option D): Presents with angular cheilitis, glossitis.

questions.text: The given condition is caused by which drug ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bleomycin

Explanation:

  • Flagellate dermatitis, also known as "flagellate erythema," is a distinctive skin reaction that can occur as a side effect of certain medications. Among the given options, the most commonly associated drug with flagellate dermatitis is Bleomycin, which is an antineoplastic medication used in the treatment of various cancers.
  • Flagellate dermatitis typically appears as linear or streak-like red or brownish patches on the skin, resembling the marks left by a whip or a scratch. It usually occurs on the trunk, extremities, or face and is believed to be an idiosyncratic reaction to Bleomycin.
  • Bleomycin-induced flagellate dermatitis is thought to be related to the drug's ability to induce the release of inflammatory mediators, resulting in the characteristic skin reaction. It typically occurs within a few days to weeks after the administration of Bleomycin and tends to resolve spontaneously once the drug is discontinued.

 

Some common side effects associated with the use of Bleomycin:

Side Effect

Description

Pulmonary Toxicity

Bleomycin is known to cause lung damage, which can lead to pulmonary fibrosis and respiratory symptoms such as cough, shortness of breath, and decreased lung function.

Skin Toxicity

Bleomycin can cause skin reactions, including flagellate dermatitis (linear streaks on the skin), erythema (redness), and skin desquamation (peeling).

Mucosal Toxicity

Bleomycin can cause mucosal damage, resulting in mouth sores, sore throat, and inflammation of the oral and nasal mucosa.

Fever

Fever is a common side effect of Bleomycin treatment and can occur shortly after administration.

Hematologic Toxicity

Bleomycin can suppress bone marrow function, leading to decreased production of blood cells, including red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.

Nail Changes

Bleomycin can cause nail abnormalities, including nail discoloration, brittle nails, and nail bed inflammation.

Allergic Reactions

Allergic reactions to Bleomycin can occur, ranging from mild rash to severe hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis.

 

Incorrrect Options:

Actinomycin (Option A): Actinomycin is an antibiotic medication used in chemotherapy. While it can cause various dermatological side effects, flagellate dermatitis is not commonly associated with Actinomycin use.

Mitomycin C (Option C): Mitomycin C is an antineoplastic medication used in the treatment of certain cancers. While it can cause skin reactions, flagellate dermatitis is not a recognized side effect commonly associated with Mitomycin C use.

Doxorubicin (Option D): Doxorubicin is an anthracycline chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer. While it can cause skin-related side effects, flagellate dermatitis is not a well-known or commonly reported side effect of Doxorubicin use.

questions.text: A patient presents with the given rash after he had taken NSAIDs for his knee pain. He reported that he developed the same rash in the same location 6 months ago when he took the same drugs for back pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fixed drug eruption

Explanation:

  • The recurrent nature of the rash in the same location after taking NSAIDs strongly supports Fixed Drug Eruption (FDE).

Fixed drug eruption:

  • Fixed drug eruption is a distinctive cutaneous allergic reaction that characteristically recurs at the same sites with the same morphology on re-exposure to the medication or other chemical agent.
  • Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction (Option B ruled out)
  • Causative drugs: Co-trimoxazole, NSAIDs, tetracyclines, sulfonamides.
  • Mediated by memory T-cells.
  • Acutely, erythematous and bullous phases of fixed eruptions, followed by well-circumscribed areas of slate-brown pigmentation
  • Site of lesions: Mucous membrane (Lips, tongues, Glans penis), face and acral areas although can occur anywhere on the skin surface.
  • Leaves residual hyperpigmentation on healing (Option A ruled out).
  • Upon reexposure, lesions develop within 30 minutes to 8 hours (Option C ruled out).
  • Treatment:
    • Stop the causative drug.
    • Topical steroids and antibiotics combinations

Incorrect Options

Drug hypersensitivity (Option A): While this is a broad term for adverse drug reactions, it doesn't specify the unique characteristic of recurrence at the same site.

Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) (Option B): PIH is a result of inflammation or injury to the skin, but it wouldn't consistently reappear in the same location with each exposure to the same drug.

Drug-induced hypermelanosis (Option D): This is a general term for increased melanin production due to drugs, but it doesn't fit the specific pattern of a solitary lesion recurring at the same site with each drug exposure.

questions.text: What is the name of the clinical sign shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dermographism

Explanation:

  • Dermographism (also called dermatographia or skin writing) is a condition where firm stroking of the skin induces an urticarial wheal within minutes.

Type of Physical Urticaria

Eliciting Factors

Urticaria factitial / Dermographism

  • Most common type, red, itchy, linear wheal appearing immediately after light stroking of the skin.

Mechanical shearing forces (wheals arising within 1-5 mins)

Cold contact urticaria

Cold objects, air, fluids, wind

Heat contact urticaria

Localized heat

Solar urticaria

UV and/or visible light

Delayed pressure urticaria (poor prognosis)

Vertical pressure (wheals arise with 3-12 hours latency)

Aquagenic urticaria

Water

Cholinergic urticaria

Increase in core body temperature by exercise or spicy food

Nikolsky Sign (Option B):

  • Nikolsky sign is seen in pemphigus vulgaris, toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS).
  • It refers to the sloughing of epidermis upon slight rubbing of the skin.

Koebner’s Phenomenon (Option C):

  • This describes the development of new skin lesions at sites of trauma in diseases like psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo.
  • Unlike dermographism, it is not immediate and takes days to develop.

Option D: Auspitz Sign (Option D):

  • Seen in psoriasis, where removal of scales leads to pinpoint bleeding due to exposure of dermal papillary capillaries.

questions.text: A farmer presented to the outpatient department with a swelling over his palm as shown in the photo. A few months back he got injured with a thorn. What is the presentation given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Implantation dermoid

Explanation: An implantation dermoid is a type of dermoid cyst that occurs due to the accidental implantation of epidermal cells into the deeper tissues following trauma, such as thorn pricks, puncture wounds, or surgical procedures.

Dermoid Cyst:

Pathophysiology:

  • Formed when epithelial tissue is trapped along the lines of embryonic fusion.

Common Sites:

  • Outer canthus of the eye
  • Post-auricular region

Clinical Features:

  • Cystic swelling (Fluctuation test positive)
  • Skin can be pinched over the swelling

Investigations:

  • X-ray/CT must be done to rule out intracranial extension before surgery

Management:

  • Surgical excision

Implantation Dermoid:

  • Occurs due to injury
  • Most common after ear piercing
  • Management: Surgical excision

Ameloblastoma (Option A):

  • is a benign odontogenic tumor generally present in the jawbone.

Embryogenic dermoid (Option B): A dermoid cyst is a benign cutaneous developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic

closure.

Sequestration dermoid (Option C): Dermoid cysts result from an abnormal alteration in fetal development. They occur due to the abnormal sequestration and inclusion of the surface ectoderm along the lines of skin fusion during embryologic development.

questions.text: The girl seen in the image has had a history of severe sunburns after just a few minutes in the sun, severe freckling in the sun-exposed areas. The most likely diagnosis is.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Xeroderma pigmentosum

Explanation: The correct answer is Xeroderma pigmentosum, as the girl has severe sunburns with minimal exposure, freckling, and sun-induced skin damage, which are hallmark features of XP.

Xeroderma Pigmentosum:

  • It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight.
  • It arises due to genetic mutations affecting genes responsible for the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway.
  • It presents with freckle-like pigmented patches, atrophic areas, and other skin abnormalities in sun-exposed areas.
  • Additionally, patients may experience ocular manifestations such as photophobia, conjunctival injection, and corneal ulcers due to UV-induced damage.
  • Systemic manifestations can include mental retardation and low intelligence.
  • Increased risk of developing skin cancers, including melanoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and basal cell carcinoma, at a young age.

Bloom Syndrome (Option A):

  • It is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by mutations in the BLM gene.
  • It presents with short stature, photosensitivity, and characteristic facial features including a long, narrow face and prominent nose, along with other physical anomalies such as micrognathia and cafe-au-lait spots.
  • Increased risk of various cancers, particularly leukaemia and lymphoma, at an early age.

Warts (Option C):

  • Warts (caused by HPV) present as localized verrucous lesions, not widespread freckling and sun sensitivity.

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (Option D):

  • SLE can cause photosensitivity, but it presents with a malar rash, systemic symptoms (fatigue, arthritis, renal involvement), and autoantibodies. XP causes DNA repair defects, not an autoimmune reaction.

Correct Answer: C) Humby’s knife

Explanation: Identification: The image shows a Humby’s knife, a surgical instrument used for harvesting split-thickness skin grafts (STSGs).

Structure:

  • A handle for grip.
  • An adjustable blade for controlling the thickness of the graft.
  • A roller to maintain uniform graft thickness.

Usage: Used in plastic and reconstructive surgery for covering wounds, burns, and ulcers.

Humby’s Knife

Feature

Details

Purpose

Harvesting split-thickness skin grafts (STSGs).

Blade Type

Single cutting blade, adjustable for thickness.

Alternative Instruments

Watson’s knife, Padgett dermatome, and Brown’s dermatome.

Advantages

Cost-effective, reusable, allows controlled thickness.

Disadvantages

Requires manual skill, risk of irregular graft thickness.

Single cutting razor (Option A): Incorrect because Humby’s knife has an adjustable blade for controlled cutting, unlike a simple razor.

Double cutting razor (Option B): Incorrect because Humby’s knife has a single cutting edge.

Finochietto knife (Option D): Incorrect because Finochietto is a rib spreader, not a skin grafting knife.
